reporting-org.narrative: International Network for Bamboo and Rattan(INBAR)

title.narrative: LARGE SCALE AND SMALLHOLDER RESTORATION AND SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF BAMBOO FORESTS AND FARMS

description.narrative: To restore and sustainably manage bamboo forests and farms

participating-org.narrative: Ethiopia Environment Forest Climate Change Commission
International Network for Bamboo and Rattan (INBAR)
International Network for Bamboo and Rattan (INBAR)

mailing-address.narrative: East Africa Regional Office INBAR, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia

recipient-country.narrative: Bamboo plantation, sustainable harvesting, and management practices.
Bamboo plantation, sustainable harvesting, and management practices.
Bamboo plantation, sustainable harvesting, and management practices.

sector.narrative: Bamboo plantation for land restoration resulting in climate change mitigation and bamboo agroforestry and smallholder planting resulting in improved resilience of smallholder farmers.
Sustainable management of bamboo forest results in improvement of ecosystem services sustainable utilisation of bamboo resources

title.narrative: Oxytenanthera abyssinica A. Rich. Munro species-site suitability matching in Ethiopia
Bamboo forests plantation and sustainable management of forests and farms

comment.narrative: Bamboo planted in new area of 1173.30 hectares. 1807(873M/934F) smallholder farmers planted bamboo in homestead and farm boundary for resilience benefits. 560.78 hectares of bamboo forests have been undertaken in sustainable harvesting and management practices.In addition EEFCCC planted ~1649.00 hectare under the Green Legacy programme of Ethiopia,1237.42 hectare bamboo forest brought under sustainable management. Overall achievement 2469.27 hectare new plantation; 4460 smallholder farmers planted bamboo for improved resilience; 1029.23 hectares bamboo bring under sustainable harvesting and management resigm and 3677 farmers benifitted.

Ethiopia site Specific matching study research report published in scientific journal(https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2773139122000015). Overall achievement 2588.27 hectare new plantation; 6145 smallholder farmers planted bamboo for improved resilience;1333.63 hectares bamboo bring under sustainable harvesting and management reign and 4954 farmers benefitted.

Three site-species matching studies are ongoing in collaboration with Ethiopia Environment Forest Research Institute(EEFRI), Kenya Forestry Research Institute(KEFRI) and National Forestry Resources Research Institute(NaFORRI). The objective of the research is to study and validate the growth and performance of indigenous bamboo species, introduced bamboo species both in theory and practice, shortlist and provide recommendation for expansion of selected species for different agro-climatic clusters and end uses. The research design, data collection methodology developed and field data collection is in progress.
During Year-1, the programme established 1295.97 hectare of new bamboo plantation accounting for 26 percent of the overall indicator.The bamboo plants were distributed to 1338 smallholder famer (595M/ 743F) achieving 13.38 percent of overall indicator.The sustainable management of forest and farms was initiated on 1400 hectare of land in Ethiopia, Kenya and Uganda and out of which 468.45 hectarewere brought under sustainable management regime with an overall achievement is 9.38 percent of the programme indicator. The sustainable management of bamboo has benefitted 935 (170M/765F)

Three site species matching study; 5000 hectare planted; 10000 (7000 M/3000 W) smallholder planted bamboo; 5000 hectares of bamboo forests and farms under sustainable management benefiting 5000(50%) women smallholder farmer; three bamboo agro-forestry model validated.
